result.execSummary:
The defendant Robert J Pettis Jr was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Burglary-Building or Dwelling [Modifiers: Repeater], a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.10(1m)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Defendant IS NOT eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program, but
IS eligible for Substance Abuse Program.
Credit for 358 days.

superMiscConds.notes:
Restitution to be paid as a Condition of Extended Supervision along with the surcharges.

  If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.

Court costs and DNA to be paid as a Condition of Extended Supervision.

  If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.
Submit to an AODA Assessment and follow through with any treatment recommended.

Maintain absolute sobriety.
Submit to random alcohol/drug screens.
Not to use or possess of alcohol or controlled substances without a valid prescription or any drug paraphernalia.
Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed.
Inform Agent of all prescriptions.
Follow through with any treatment/counseling including any mental health recommended by Agent.
Provide DNA sample if not already provided.

Arraignment on July 30, 2015 at 10:00 am.

Defendant Robert J Pettis in court, in custody, with attorney Christina Balistreri for  Mark A. Pecora.   Timothy Suha appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Ass't Chief Jason Hennen from the Village of Elm Grove was sworn and testified on behalf of the State. Cross examination by the defense. State rests. No testimony by the defense. Testimony is closed. State moves for bind over. Defense moves for dismissal with no arguments.   Court finds probable cause to believe that a felony was committed and binds the defendant over for trial.   Bail remains as fixed.  Arraignment scheduled for July 30, 2015 at 10:00 am.
